start.speaker: Pixel
start.text: Welcome to your first Python adventure! üéÆ I'm super excited to teach you programming!
start.followUp: You know what's cool? Every game you've ever played started with someone typing their first line of code, just like you're about to do!

options.text: Uhh... is this gonna be really hard?

reassurance.speaker: Pixel
reassurance.text: Not at all! Think of it like learning the controls in a new game - seems tricky at first, but soon it becomes second nature!
reassurance.followUp: We'll start super simple. Want to make Python say hello?

firstPrint.speaker: Pixel
firstPrint.text: Okay, so here's your first superpower - the print() function! It's basically like giving Python a voice!
firstPrint.followUp: See those quotes? That's how Python knows what to say. Which one looks right to you?

options.text: The one with quotes looks right!

printError.speaker: Pixel
printError.text: Ooh, so close! But Python's a bit picky - it needs those quotes, like putting quotation marks around someone's speech!
printError.codeExample: print('Hello, World!')  # The quotes are important!
printError.followUp: Without quotes, Python gets confused and thinks you're talking about something that doesn't exist yet!

options.text: Ah, got it! With quotes then!

explainQuotes.speaker: Pixel
explainQuotes.text: Great question! So here's the thing - without quotes, Python thinks Hello is like... a secret code word it should know!
explainQuotes.codeExample:
print(Hello)  # Python: 'What's Hello? I don't know that!'
print('Hello')  # Python: 'Oh! You want me to SAY Hello!'
explainQuotes.followUp: It's like the difference between saying 'Mario' versus 'Say the word Mario' - totally different!

options.text: Ohhh that totally makes sense now!

printSuccess.speaker: Pixel
printSuccess.text: üéâ YES! Look at you! You just wrote actual code! You're officially a programmer now!
printSuccess.followUp: You can make Python say literally anything - jokes, game messages, whatever! What should we print next?

options.text: I want to print my name!

morePrints.speaker: Pixel
morePrints.text: Nice! You're a natural! Okay, here's where it gets really cool - we can save stuff to use later!
morePrints.followUp: Imagine having treasure chests in your code where you can store things... that's basically what variables are!

options.text: Can I call them whatever I want?

variableNames.speaker: Pixel
variableNames.text: Pretty much! It's like creating usernames - you've got freedom but there are a few rules!
variableNames.codeExample:
player_name = 'Pixel'  # Perfect!
hero123 = 'Link'       # Totally works!
123hero = 'Mario'      # Nope - numbers can't go first!
variableNames.followUp: Just remember: no spaces (use underscores), and numbers can't be first. Easy!

options.text: Makes sense! Let's make some variables!

variables.speaker: Pixel
variables.text: Alright, time to create your first variable! Just pick a name, add an equals sign, and boom - storage!
variables.followUp: See that? We just stuffed 'Pixel' into a box called player_name! Now we can use it anywhere!

options.text: I want to store a number!

numberVariable.speaker: Pixel
numberVariable.text: Boom! You just stored a number! And look - no quotes needed this time!
numberVariable.codeExample:
score = 100
lives = 3
print('Score:', score)
print('Lives:', lives)
numberVariable.followUp: Python's smart enough to know 100 is a number. No quotes = it's math time!

options.text: Wait, can I add them together?
What other stuff can variables hold?

stringVariable.speaker: Pixel
stringVariable.text: Nice! You just made a 'string' variable - fancy programmer word for text!
stringVariable.codeExample:
game_title = 'My Awesome Game'
print('Now playing:', game_title)
stringVariable.followUp: Strings are perfect for all the words in your game - character names, dialogue, everything!

stringCombine.speaker: Pixel
stringCombine.text: Oh yeah! Watch this - strings can stick together like LEGO blocks!
stringCombine.codeExample:
first = 'Super'
last = 'Mario'
full_name = first + ' ' + last
print(full_name)  # Ta-da! Super Mario!
stringCombine.followUp: The plus sign is like glue for words! Perfect for building game messages on the fly!

options.text: That's awesome! What else can Python do?

mathPreview.speaker: Pixel
mathPreview.text: Oh absolutely! Python's basically a calculator on steroids! Watch this!
mathPreview.codeExample:
score = 100
bonus = 50
total = score + bonus
print('Total score:', total)  # Boom! 150!
mathPreview.followUp: Next lesson we'll go crazy with math - for now, just know it works!

dataTypes.speaker: Pixel
dataTypes.text: Python's got different types of data - think of them like different items in your inventory!
dataTypes.codeExample:
# Strings (text)
player = 'Hero'

# Integers (whole numbers)  
level = 5

# Floats (decimals)
health = 95.5

# Booleans (true/false)
game_over = False
dataTypes.followUp: Each type does different things - we'll use them all to make amazing games!

options.text: Can I see this in action?

moreExamples.speaker: Pixel
moreExamples.text: Check this out - variables working together like an RPG character sheet!
moreExamples.codeExample:
# Game character stats
character_name = 'Shadow Knight'
health = 100
mana = 50
level = 1
is_alive = True

# Display the stats
print('Character:', character_name)
print('HP:', health, '/ MP:', mana)
print('Level:', level)
moreExamples.followUp: See? Variables are basically how games remember everything - scores, lives, player names!

options.text: This is so cool! Let me try!

practice.speaker: Pixel
practice.text: Time for a mini challenge! Can you create a simple game intro using what you've learned?
practice.followUp: Create variables for a game title and player name, then print a welcome message!

practiceHint.speaker: Pixel
practiceHint.text: No problem! Here's a template to help you out!
practiceHint.codeExample:
game_title = '???'  # Put your game name here
player_name = '???'  # Put your player name here
print('Welcome to', game_title)
print('Good luck,', player_name)
practiceHint.followUp: Just replace the ??? with your own text!

options.text: Got it! Let me try now

practiceCheck.speaker: Pixel
practiceCheck.text: Fantastic work! You've mastered the basics of Python! üèÜ
practiceCheck.codeExample:
game_title = 'Dragon Quest'
player_name = 'Hero'
print('Welcome to', game_title)
print('Good luck,', player_name)
practiceCheck.followUp: You learned print(), variables, and different data types - that's the foundation of all programming!

lessonComplete.speaker: Pixel
lessonComplete.text: üéä LEVEL 1 COMPLETE! You're officially a Python programmer now!
lessonComplete.followUp: You've unlocked the power to make computers do your bidding! Ready to level up?

options.text: Take me to Lesson 2 - Math & Operations!
I want to start making a game now!

extraPractice.speaker: Pixel
extraPractice.text: Great idea! Practice makes perfect! Try these exercises:
extraPractice.codeExample:
# Exercise 1: Create a character
# Make variables for: name, class, level, health

# Exercise 2: Print a story
# Use variables to print a short game intro

# Exercise 3: Mix it up
# Try storing different types of data
extraPractice.followUp: Take your time experimenting! When you're ready, move on to the next lesson!
